item.title: Missing Stack trace when eliding the await keyword
item.description: You may have heard that when you elide the await keyword in a method that returns a Task or Task<T>, you lose the stack trace. Buy why does that happen? Let's find out!

item.title: Bridging the gap between neural networks and functions · @sebinsua
item.description: A layperson software engineer’s guide to understanding neural networks, examining how the prerequisites for backpropagation gave us magical function approximators but at the cost of interpretability.

item.title: How to give code review as a junior developer?
item.description: By focusing on learning, providing constructive feedback with a positive tone, and embracing the opportunity to contribute, junior developers can make valuable contributions to code quality and their own growth. Code reviews are essential for skill development and fostering collaboration within development teams.

item.title: Gabriele Svelto (@gabrielesvelto@fosstodon.org)
item.description:
On Monday morning we (Mozilla) detected a very large crash spike affecting #Firefox users on Linux, specifically on an older version of a Debian-based distribution.
It turned out to be an interesting bug involving the #Linux kernel and #Google JavaScript code so let me tell you about it.
A thread 🧵
https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1839669 1/6

item.title: Episode 54: Cleaning your Big Ball of Mud using CQS - with Matt Hunt
item.description: In this episode, I was thrilled to be joined by Matt Hunt to chat about using the CQS pattern to improve your codebase quality and help avoid writing those ‘Big Ball of Mud’ code-bases that sadly we see way too often in our industry! CQS (Command Query Separation) is a pattern that states that a method should either be a command that performs an action or a query that returns data, but not both.
